p: Migrants in high income, low prevalence countries can be disproportionately affected by HIV, with higher diagnosis rates and a greater likelihood of being diagnosed late, with a CD4 count under 350 cells/ul [ 1â€“ 3]. Historically migrants from high prevalence countries such as in Sub-Saharan Africa have been the most affected, but emerging evidence from Europe suggests this is changing, with decreases in HIV diagnoses attributed to heterosexual exposure in African migrants and increases in new HIV diagnoses attributed to male-to-male sex in Latin American migrants [ 1, 2].
